column24: I had difficulty in swallowing. Occasionally, when I am feeling particularly anxious or stressed, I have noticed a slight difficulty in swallowing. It's not a constant issue, but it does happen at times.
column25: I couldn't seem to get any enjoyment out of the things I did. The emotional strain and pressure I am under have made it difficult to find pleasure and enjoyment in the activities I engage in. Things that used to bring me joy now feel empty and unfulfilling.
column26: I was aware of the action of my heart in the absence of physical exertion (eg, sense of heart rate increase, heart missing a beat). Occasionally, especially when I am feeling anxious or stressed, I become more aware of my heartbeat. It's not a constant feeling, but it does happen at times.
column27: I felt down-hearted and blue. The ongoing difficulties and emotional strain have left me feeling constantly downcast and sad. It's been hard to maintain a sense of positivity and happiness.
column28: I found that I was very irritable. The high levels of stress I am experiencing have made me more irritable and easily annoyed. Small things that wouldn't usually bother me now trigger feelings of irritability and frustration.
column29: I felt I was close to panic. The ongoing stress and pressure have left me feeling constantly on edge and prone to panic. It feels like I am just one step away from falling into a full-blown panic attack.
column30: I found it hard to calm down after something upset me. When I am upset or stressed, it takes a long time for me to calm down and return to a stable emotional state. It feels like my emotions are on a constant rollercoaster ride.
column31: I feared that I would be "thrown" by some trivial but unfamiliar task. The high levels of stress and pressure have made me more fearful and anxious about unfamiliar tasks. I worry that I won't be able to handle even the simplest of tasks due to the state I am in.
column32: I was unable to become enthusiastic about anything. The emotional strain and difficulties I am facing have left me feeling constantly disengaged and lacking enthusiasm. It's been hard to find motivation and excitement in the midst of this turmoil.
column33: I found it difficult to tolerate interruptions to what I was doing. The constant pressure and stress make it incredibly challenging to focus and stay engaged in my work. Interruptions feel even more disruptive and irritating than usual.
column34: I was in a state of nervous tension. The ongoing stress and emotional strain have left me in a constant state of tension and anxiety. It feels like I am always on high alert and unable to fully relax.
column35: I felt I was pretty worthless. The strain on my relationships and the difficulties I am facing in my PhD program have led me to question my worth and value. I often feel like I am not meeting expectations and falling short.
column36: I was intolerant of anything that kept me from getting on with what I was doing. The high levels of stress and pressure have made me more impatient and intolerant of anything that interrupts my work or progress. I just want to get things done and move forward.
column37: I felt terrified. The ongoing stress and difficulties have left me feeling constantly fearful and terrified. It's hard to shake off the feeling of impending doom and uncertainty.
column38: I could see nothing in the future to be hopeful about. The emotional strain and challenges I am facing have made it difficult to see a positive future. It feels like there is no light at the end of the tunnel.
column39: I felt that life was meaningless. The ongoing difficulties and emotional strain have left me questioning the meaning and purpose of life. It's been challenging to find a sense of meaning and fulfillment in the midst of this turmoil.
column40: I found myself getting agitated. The stress and pressure I am under have made me more easily agitated and prone to feeling restless. Small things that wouldn't usually bother me can now trigger feelings of agitation.
column41: I was worried about situations in which I might panic and make a fool of myself. The constant anxiety and pressure have made me more fearful of situations where I might experience a panic attack or embarrass myself. These worries often loom over me, adding to my overall anxiety.
column42: I experienced trembling (eg, in the hands). At times when I am feeling particularly anxious or stressed, I have noticed slight trembling or shaking, especially in my hands. It's not a constant issue, but it does happen occasionally.
column43: I found it difficult to work up the initiative to do things. The ongoing stress and emotional strain have made it hard to find the motivation and drive to initiate tasks and activities. It feels like I am constantly dragging myself to get things done.

column2: I found myself getting upset by quite trivial things. I have been feeling overwhelmed with my workload and the pressure to meet deadlines, so even small setbacks and inconveniences have been causing me to feel more easily upset.
column3: I was aware of dryness of my mouth. The stress and anxiety that I have been experiencing have led to increased physiological symptoms, including dryness of my mouth due to elevated levels of tension.
column4: I couldn't seem to experience any positive feeling at all. The constant stress and strained relationships with my advisors have been taking a toll on my mental well-being, making it difficult to find joy or feel positive about the work I'm doing.
column5: I experienced breathing difficulty (e.g., excessively rapid breathing, breathlessness in the absence of physical exertion). While I haven't experienced severe breathing difficulty, there have been moments where I've noticed my breathing becoming faster and feeling slightly breathless due to the overall stress I've been under.
column6: I just couldn't seem to get going. The emotional toll of the strained relationships with my advisors has made it harder for me to find motivation and momentum in my research and everyday tasks.
column7: I tended to over-react to situations. Because my emotions have been heightened due to the strained relationships with my advisors, I've found myself overreacting to even minor challenges or setbacks, resulting in unnecessary emotional distress.
column8: I had a feeling of shakiness (e.g., legs going to give way). I have occasionally experienced a sense of shakiness in my body, particularly when I was confronting uncomfortable situations or when I felt overwhelmed by the strained relationships with my advisors.
column9: I found it difficult to relax. The constant pressure and strained relationships have made it incredibly challenging for me to find moments of relaxation. I often feel like I should be working or worrying about my research, which prevents me from fully unwinding and recharging.
column10: I found myself in situations that made me so anxious I was most relieved when they ended. I have found myself in meetings or discussions with my advisors that have caused a significant amount of anxiety and discomfort. The relief I feel when these situations come to an end is palpable.
column11: I felt that I had nothing to look forward to. The strain in my relationships with my advisors and the emotional toll it has taken on me have resulted in a lack of excitement or anticipation for the future. It's challenging to maintain a sense of hope or positivity under these circumstances.
column12: I found myself getting upset rather easily. The constant stress and emotional strain have made me more sensitive, causing me to get upset more easily even in situations that wouldn't typically trigger such a strong emotional response.
column13: I felt that I was using a lot of nervous energy. The combination of stress and strained relationships has led to heightened levels of anxiety and nervousness. I have been expending a lot of mental and emotional energy trying to navigate these situations, which leaves me feeling depleted.
column14: I felt sad and depressed. The strain in my relationships with my advisors and the emotional toll it has taken on me have left me feeling consistently downcast and experiencing symptoms of depression.
column15: I found myself getting impatient when I was delayed in any way (e.g., elevators, traffic lights, being kept waiting). The stress and anxiety that I have been experiencing have made me less tolerant of delays or any interruptions to my already demanding schedule. Waiting for even small things has been incredibly frustrating.
column16: I had a feeling of faintness. The overall stress and emotional strain have led to occasional feelings of lightheadedness and faintness, particularly when I am in particularly challenging or uncomfortable situations.
column17: I felt that I had lost interest in just about everything. column18: I felt I wasn't worth much as a person. The strained relationships with my advisors, coupled with the lack of respect I feel I receive, have significantly impacted my self-worth. column19: I felt that I was rather touchy. The stress and emotional strain have made me more easily agitated and reactive. I find myself being more sensitive to criticism or negative feedback, which further exacerbates the strained relationships with my advisors.
column20: I perspired noticeably (e.g., hands sweaty), in the absence of high temperatures or physical exertion.
